A 27-year multigravida presents at 6 weeks complaining of fever and a pruritic rash. You diagnose her with varicella zoster virus. Three of your other pregnant patients were in the office waiting room at the same time as this patient and you are concerned, they may have been exposed. Two of them report having a history of varicella during childhood and the 3 rd reports no history of either vaccination or natural infection. What is the next best plan for her?

options.label: B
options.text: VZV serological testing followed by vaccination if seronegative

options.label: C
options.text: VZV serological testing followed by varicella zoster Immunoglobulin if seronegative

options.label: D
options.text: VZV serological testing followed by varicella zoster immunoglobulin and vaccination if seronegative

questions.correct_answer: C. VZV serological testing followed by varicella zoster Immunoglobulin if seronegative
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Chickenpox in Pregnancy
  • • There are 2 important aspects to chicken pox in pregnancy:
  • • Pregnant patient presents with rash (Chicken pox) Pregnant patient presents with contact with a person who has chicken pox, and is therefore at risk of developing chicken pox
  • • Pregnant patient presents with rash (Chicken pox)
  • • Pregnant patient presents with contact with a person who has chicken pox, and is therefore at risk of developing chicken pox
  • • Scenario 1: Pregnant patient with rash i.e. she has already developed chicken pox
  • • Avoid contact with susceptible individuals, until the lesions have crusted over. This is usually about 5 days after the onset of the rash. Symptomatic treatment and hygiene is advised to prevent secondary bacterial infection of the lesions. Oral Acyclovir should be prescribed Intravenous Acyclovir should be given to all pregnant women with severe chickenpox. VZIG has no therapeutic benefit once chickenpox has developed . Women who develop chickenpox in pregnancy should be referred to a fetal medicine specialist, at 16–20 weeks or 5 weeks after infection, for discussion and detailed ultrasound examination (Risk of congenital varicella) If maternal infection occurs in the last 4 weeks of a woman’s pregnancy, there is a significant risk of varicella infection of the newborn. A planned delivery should normally be avoided for at least 7 days after the onset of the maternal rash to allow for the passive transfer of antibodies from mother to child.

A planned delivery should normally be avoided for at least 7 days after the onset of the maternal rash to allow for the passive transfer of antibodies from mother to child.
  • • Scenario 2: Pregnant patient with history of contact with a person who has chicken pox
  • • Determine if she has been vaccinated against chicken pox or has had the infection earlier (i.e. immunized) IF immunized, nothing further need be done If not sure of status: Do IgG VZV If IgG VZV is positive: she is immunized and nothing need be done If she is IgG VZV negative or she is unimmunized: This means she is susceptible and should be given VZ IG within 10 days of contact.

questions.text: Which of the following explains the reason why Nitrates and Sildenafil should not be prescribed together?

options.label: A
options.text: Nitrates and Sildenafil both cause hypertension.

options.label: B
options.text: Sildenafil inhibits the metabolism of Nitrates leading to toxicity.

options.label: C
options.text: Co-administration can cause severe hypotension due to the potentiation of the action of Nitrates.

options.label: D
options.text: There is no specific interaction between Nitrates and Sildenafil.

questions.correct_answer: C. Co-administration can cause severe hypotension due to the potentiation of the action of Nitrates.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Co-administration can cause severe hypotension due to the potentiation of the action of Nitrates.

Explanation:

  • • Option A is incorrect because both Nitrates and Sildenafil cause vasodilation which would lower, not raise, blood pressure.
  • • Option B is incorrect because Sildenafil doesn't inhibit the metabolism of Nitrates. Instead, it inhibits phosphodiesterase-5 (PDE5), an enzyme that breaks down cGMP.
  • • Option C is correct because Nitrates increase the level of cGMP causing vasodilation and lowering blood pressure. When Sildenafil (a PDE5 inhibitor) is also administered, it prevents the breakdown of cGMP, leading to a further increase in cGMP levels and enhancing the vasodilatory effect of Nitrates. This can cause severe hypotension.
  • • Option D is incorrect because there is a significant interaction between Nitrates and Sildenafil, which can lead to severe hypotension. Therefore, they should not be administered together.

Neurological symptoms are observed in all of the following diseases EXCEPT:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Gaucher's disease

Explanation:

  • • Explanation of other options:
  • • Option A. Tay-Sachs disease
  • • Option A. Tay-Sachs disease
  • • Tay-Sachs disease is a rare genetic disorder characterized by the accumulation of a fatty substance called GM2 ganglioside in the nerve cells of the brain and spinal cord. This accumulation leads to progressive damage to the nervous system, causing neurological symptoms such as developmental regression, muscle weakness, loss of motor skills, and seizures.
  • • Tay-Sachs disease is a rare genetic disorder characterized by the accumulation of a fatty substance called GM2 ganglioside in the nerve cells of the brain and spinal cord. This accumulation leads to progressive damage to the nervous system, causing neurological symptoms such as developmental regression, muscle weakness, loss of motor skills, and seizures.
  • • Tay-Sachs disease is a rare genetic disorder characterized by the accumulation of a fatty substance called GM2 ganglioside in the nerve cells of the brain and spinal cord. This accumulation leads to progressive damage to the nervous system, causing neurological symptoms such as developmental regression, muscle weakness, loss of motor skills, and seizures.
  • • Tay-Sachs disease is a rare genetic disorder characterized by the accumulation of a fatty substance called GM2 ganglioside in the nerve cells of the brain and spinal cord.
  • • This accumulation leads to progressive damage to the nervous system, causing neurological symptoms such as developmental regression, muscle weakness, loss of motor skills, and seizures.
  • • Option B. Niemann-Pick disease
  • • Option B. Niemann-Pick disease
  • • Niemann-Pick disease is a group of inherited metabolic disorders that result in the accumulation of lipids, particularly sphingomyelin, in various tissues and organs. Different subtypes of Niemann-Pick disease exist, but most of them involve neurological symptoms. These symptoms may include progressive intellectual and motor decline, seizures, muscle stiffness, and impaired coordination.
  • • Niemann-Pick disease is a group of inherited metabolic disorders that result in the accumulation of lipids, particularly sphingomyelin, in various tissues and organs.
  • • Different subtypes of Niemann-Pick disease exist, but most of them involve neurological symptoms. These symptoms may include progressive intellectual and motor decline, seizures, muscle stiffness, and impaired coordination.
  • • Option D. GM1 gangliosidosis
  • • Option D. GM1 gangliosidosis
  • • GM1 gangliosidosis is also a rare genetic disorder characterized by the deficiency of an enzyme called beta-galactosidase. This deficiency leads to the accumulation of GM1 ganglioside in various tissues, including the brain and nerve cells. The neurological symptoms of GM1 gangliosidosis are progressive and include developmental regression, muscle stiffness, seizures, loss of motor skills, and intellectual disability.
  • • GM1 gangliosidosis is also a rare genetic disorder characterized by the deficiency of an enzyme called beta-galactosidase. This deficiency leads to the accumulation of GM1 ganglioside in various tissues, including the brain and nerve cells.
  • • The neurological symptoms of GM1 gangliosidosis are progressive and include developmental regression, muscle stiffness, seizures, loss of motor skills, and intellectual disability.
  • • In summary, while neurological symptoms are observed in Tay-Sachs disease, Niemann-Pick disease, and GM1 gangliosidosis, they are not typically observed in Gaucher's disease, making it the exception among the given options.

A 24-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with complaints of sudden onset shortness of breath, heart palpitations, and a fear that she is “going crazy”. She has no history of similar episodes. On examination, her heart rate is 110 bpm, blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg, and her physical examination is otherwise unremarkable. Laboratory tests, including complete blood count, electrolytes, cardiac enzymes, and thyroid function tests, are within normal limits. An ECG shows sinus tachycardia with no ST or T wave changes. Based on the most likely diagnosis, what is the next best step in management?

options.label: D
options.text: Start long-term selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor therapy

questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Administer oral benzodiazepines

Explanation:

  • • This patient’s symptoms of palpitations, shortness of breath, and the fear of going crazy are suggestive of a panic attack. In the acute setting, the first line treatment for a panic attack is a benzodiazepine, which can provide immediate relief from acute symptoms. Benzodiazepines can be administered orally in this case as the patient is conscious, cooperative, and able to swallow. Cognitive-behavioral therapy and SSRIs are effective for long-term management of panic disorder, but they do not provide the immediate relief that is necessary in an acute panic attack. Furosemide is a diuretic and is not indicated in this case.

questions.text: Mechanism by which students view this image:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Dichroic mirror

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The picture shows a specimen under fluorescence microscope. The specimen is illuminated with light of a specific band, which is absorbed by the fluorescent dye, causing it to emit light of a weaker band and hence a different color. In a properly configured microscope, only the emission light should reach the eye or detector and not the illuminating light scattered by the background This produces a high contrast image where the fluorescent structures are superimposed on a dark background. The dichroic mirrors used in fluorescence microscopes allow the weaker emitted light to pass through it while reflecting the illuminating light back.

A patient with acute lymphoblastic Leukemia is being treated with a medication that interferes with protein synthesis by causing the breakdown of asparagine. Which of the following drugs is this patient likely receiving?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. L-Asparaginase

Explanation:

  • • Each of the listed drugs has a different mechanism of action.
  • • 6-Mercaptopurine is a purine analog that acts by inhibiting purine synthesis, which is required for the synthesis of DNA during the S phase of the cell cycle. Mitomycin is an alkylating agent, leading to DNA damage by creating cross links. Actinomycin causes single strand breaks in DNA and blocks RNA transcription. L-Asparaginase is the correct answer. It works by breaking down asparagine, an amino acid that is essential for protein synthesis and the growth of cancer cells. Some cancer cells, such as those in acute lymphoblastic leukemia, are unable to make enough asparagine and are dependent on the supply of asparagine from the blood. By breaking down asparagine, L-Asparaginase deprives the cancer cells of this necessary amino acid and inhibits their growth.
  • • 6-Mercaptopurine is a purine analog that acts by inhibiting purine synthesis, which is required for the synthesis of DNA during the S phase of the cell cycle.
  • • Mitomycin is an alkylating agent, leading to DNA damage by creating cross links.
  • • Actinomycin causes single strand breaks in DNA and blocks RNA transcription.
  • • L-Asparaginase is the correct answer. It works by breaking down asparagine, an amino acid that is essential for protein synthesis and the growth of cancer cells.   • • Rifampicin is a first line antitubercular drug that works by blocking the RNA polymerase enzyme, thus inhibiting the synthesis of mRNA and, consequently, protein synthesis. This mechanism of action gives it a bactericidal effect against mycobacteria, including those causing tuberculosis and leprosy, whether they are located intracellularly or extracellularly. The other drugs listed – Isoniazid, Ethambutol, and Pyrazinamide – also have antitubercular activity, but they do not function by blocking the RNA polymerase enzyme.

A 37-year-old man presents to the outpatient clinic with symptoms of depression and recent suicidal ideation. He has a history of frequent mood swings, irritability, and periods of intense euphoria followed by depressive episodes. The psychiatrist is considering adding a medication to his treatment regimen that has been shown to have anti-suicidal properties. Which of the following medications would be most appropriate?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Lithium

Explanation:

  • • Lithium is a mood stabilizer frequently used in the treatment of bipolar disorder. One of the unique aspects of lithium, in comparison to other mood stabilizers and psychiatric medications, is its demonstrated anti-suicidal properties. Multiple studies have shown that lithium reduces suicide and all-cause mortality in patients with mood disorders, such as bipolar disorder and depression.
  • • Fluoxetine is an SSRI antidepressant often used to treat depression and anxiety disorders but does not specifically have anti-suicidal properties. Olanzapine is an atypical antipsychotic used in the treatment of schizophrenia and bipolar disorder but also does not have specific anti-suicidal properties. Donepezil is used in the treatment of Alzheimer’s disease and is not typically used for mood disorders or suicidality.

questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Amniocentesis is the most common prenatal diagnostic procedure. Indications for amniocentesis include: Diagnosis of fetal genetic disorders Diagnosis of Congenital infection Evaluation of anemia in Rh alloimmunization Determination of Fetal lung maturity Following amniocentesis, genetic analysis can be done using Chromosomal microarray (CMA) – to assess copy number gains or losses: can be performed directly on uncultured amniocytes Karyotype analysis for aneuploidy requires cultures amniocytes FISH to identify gain or loss of specific chromosomes. Procedure: Ultrasound guided Done between 15- 20weeks Anterior placentation seen in 60% and blood-tinged fluid is more frequent if there is transplacental passage of the needle. For fetal karyotype, about 20 -30 ml withdrawn. Procedure related loss: 0.1 – 0.3 % when performed by an experienced provider. Early amniocentesis (11-14 weeks): significantly higher rate of procedure related complications; like clubfoot, amnionic fluid leakage and fetal loss. Not done anymore.

Which of the following statements about the hard palate is NOT correct?

options.label: A
options.text: The central part of the hard palate's bony structure is covered by a firmly attached mucosa

options.label: B
options.text: The keratinised stratified squamous epithelium of the hard palate can be orthokeratinised or parakeratinised

options.label: C
options.text: The mucosa that covers the hard palate has a distinct keratinized layer known as the stratum corneum

options.label: D
options.text: The hard palate lacks a submucosal layer with blood vessels in the lateral parts

questions.correct_answer: D. The hard palate lacks a submucosal layer with blood vessels in the lateral parts
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. The hard palate lacks a submucosal layer with blood vessels in the lateral parts.

Explanation:

  • • The hard palate is made up of keratinised stratified squamous epithelium, a submucosa, and a minor salivary gland. This keratinised stratified squamous epithelium varies regionally and can be orthokeratinised or parakeratinised (found in hard palate and gingiva).
  • • The central part of the hard palate's bony structure is covered by a firmly attached mucosa. The hard palate has a submucosal layer with blood vessels in the lateral parts. Minor mucous salivary glands can be found in the submucosa in the back of the hard palate.
  • • The mucosa that covers the hard palate has a distinct keratinized layer known as the stratum corneum. Capillaries also loop up into connective tissue papillae.
  • • The presence of relatively high connective tissue papillae projecting into the overlying epithelium is a distinguishing feature of keratinized regions in the oral cavity. Keratinized epithelium is associated with high connective tissue papillae. In the oral cavity, this type of keratinization is known as orthokeratinized stratified squamous epithelium.
  • • (Note: In the orthokeratinized epithelium, cell nuclei disappear in the keratinized layer, whereas in the parakeratinized epithelium, flattened, highly condensed nuclei remain in the keratinized layer's cell cytoplasm until exfoliation)

questions.text: Which statement is true regarding measurements taken for the Pelvic Organ Prolapse Quantification (POP-Q) examination?

options.label: A
options.text: All are taken at rest, except for total vaginal length, which is obtained during Valsalva

options.label: B
options.text: Point D is omitted in the absence of a cervix

options.label: C
options.text: GH is measured from the midline of the posterior hymenal ring to the mid-anal opening

options.label: D
options.text: Point Aa corresponds to the most distal portion of any part of the upper/proximal anterior vaginal wall

questions.correct_answer: C. GH is measured from the midline of the posterior hymenal ring to the mid-anal opening
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • In 1996, the International Continence Society defined the Pelvic Organ Prolapse Quantification (POP-Q) system. Prolapse in each segment is measured relative to the hymen, which is an anatomic landmark that can be identified consistently. Six points are located with reference to the plane of the hymen: two on the anterior vaginal wall (points Aa and Ba), two at the apical vagina (points C and D), and two on the posterior vaginal wall (points Ap and Bp) The genital hiatus (Gh), perineal body (Pb), and total vaginal length (TVL) are also measured. All POP-Q points, except TVL, are measured during patient Valsalva and should reflect maximum protrusion. Anterior Vaginal Wall Points Point Aa defines a point that lies in the midline of the anterior vaginal wall and is 3 cm proximal to the external urethral meatus. This corresponds to the proximal location of the urethra-vesical crease. Point Ba represents the most distal position of any part of the upper anterior vaginal wall, that is, the segment of vagina that normally would extend cephalad rom point Aa. It is –3 cm in the absence of prolapse.
  • • In 1996, the International Continence Society defined the Pelvic Organ Prolapse Quantification (POP-Q) system.
  • • Prolapse in each segment is measured relative to the hymen, which is an anatomic landmark that can be identified consistently.
  • • Six points are located with reference to the plane of the hymen: two on the anterior vaginal wall (points Aa and Ba), two at the apical vagina (points C and D), and two on the posterior vaginal wall (points Ap and Bp)
  • • The genital hiatus (Gh), perineal body (Pb), and total vaginal length (TVL) are also measured.
  • • All POP-Q points, except TVL, are measured during patient Valsalva and should reflect maximum protrusion.

This corresponds to the proximal location of the urethra-vesical crease. Point Ba represents the most distal position of any part of the upper anterior vaginal wall, that is, the segment of vagina that normally would extend cephalad rom point Aa. It is –3 cm in the absence of prolapse.

Point Ba represents the most distal position of any part of the upper anterior vaginal wall, that is, the segment of vagina that normally would extend cephalad rom point Aa.   • • Point Ba represents the most distal position of any part of the upper anterior vaginal wall, that is, the segment of vagina that normally would extend cephalad rom point Aa. It is –3 cm in the absence of prolapse.
  • • Apical Vaginal Points Point C defines a point that is at either the most distal edge of the cervix or the leading edge of the vaginal cuff after total hysterectomy. Point D defines a point that represents the location of the posterior fornix in a woman who still has a cervix. It is omitted in the absence of a cervix. questions.text: A 10-year-old child is brought by her mother to her primary care physician with a history of chronic shortness of breath and fatigue. She reports that her symptoms have been progressively worsening over the past year, and she is no longer able to perform her usual activities of daily living without experiencing significant dyspnea. On physical examination, the physician notes a prominent jugular venous pulse with a giant "a" wave and a soft systolic murmur best heard at the left lower sternal border. An electrocardiogram shows right atrial enlargement, right ventricular hypertrophy, and right bundle branch block. An echocardiogram is ordered, which reveals a displaced tricuspid valve into the right ventricle, with severe tricuspid regurgitation and a small right ventricle. What is the likely appearance on CXR?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The given scenario describes a typical case of Ebstein anomaly. The CXR depicts an enlarged, box-shaped cardiac silhouette, that is characteristically seen in Ebstein's anomaly.
  • • Option A: Egg in cup sign: Calcific pericarditis typically appears as a dense, curvilinear, or band-like opacity that surrounds the heart, often described as a "shaggy heart" appearance. The calcification can also extend into the adjacent mediastinal fat, creating a dense, well-defined line that separates the heart from the lungs.
  • • Option A:
  • • Option B: Egg on side: This is a radiological sign seen in TGA. Transposition of the Great Arteries, which is a congenital heart defect in which the pulmonary artery and aorta, are switched (or "transposed") in position. This means that the aorta arises from the right ventricle, and the pulmonary artery arises from the left ventricle.
  • • Option B:
  • • Option C: Money bag sign is typically seen in pericardial effusion.
  • • Option C:

questions.text: Which of the following is the most commonly used radiation sensitizer for the treatment of cervical cancer?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Current evidence indicates that chemotherapy given concurrently with radiation therapy significantly improves overall and disease- free survival rates of women with cervical cancer. Chemoradiation is also associated with superior survival rates compared with pelvic and extended- eld paraaortic region irradiation alone. Cisplatin based chemotherapy should be considered in women undergoing radiation or cervical cancer Of chemotherapy agents, cisplatin-containing regimens have been associated with the best survival rates

Which of the following is NOT a female contraceptive?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Although condoms are a contraceptive method used during sexual intercourse, they are not specifically a "female" contraceptive option. They are typically used by males, although there are also female condoms. The other options listed (IUD, birth control pills, and tubal ligation) are specifically for females. An IUD is a small device inserted into the uterus to prevent pregnancy, birth control pills are taken orally to prevent ovulation, and tubal ligation is a surgical procedure that permanently blocks the fallopian tubes to prevent pregnancy.

Which of the following statements is NOT correct about the Revised National Tuberculosis Control Program (RNTCP) in India?

options.label: B
options.text: DOTS strategy was implemented as a part of this program.

options.label: C
options.text: The program focuses exclusively on the treatment and control of pulmonary tuberculosis.

options.label: D
options.text: The program aims to detect at least 70% of the estimated infectious TB cases.

questions.correct_answer: C. The program focuses exclusively on the treatment and control of pulmonary tuberculosis.
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • The Revised National Tuberculosis Control Program (RNTCP) came in 1992 by the Government of India with the aim of detecting at least 70% of the estimated infectious TB cases and curing at least 85% of these detected cases. The program uses the Directly Observed Treatment, Short-course (DOTS) strategy which is recommended by the World Health Organization (WHO). However, the program does not solely focus on the treatment and control of pulmonary tuberculosis, it also addresses other forms of TB including extra-pulmonary tuberculosis.
